Hard is the lot of those who toil,</br>From morn to night throughout the year;</br>For tho' they till a fruitful soil,</br>No comforts now their labour cheer.
Plenty with them no more is found,</br>No more with wholesome viands fed;</br>The hand that plows and sows the ground,</br>Can scarce obtain its daily bread.
The village where contentment smil'd,</br>Is overcast with cheerless gloom;</br>And joys that labour once beguil'd,</br>To want and penury give room.
Ev'n sober industry and care,</br>The cottage bliss insure no more!</br>For now the peasant in despair,</br>Sees the gaunt wolf beset his door.
Cheerless at dawn to work he goes,</br>Cheerless returns at latest eve:</br>Nor meets the partner of his woes,</br>But o'er their helpless babes to grieve.
On his incessant toil depend,</br>Their food and raiment, house and fire;</br>Yet all to find without a friend,</br>Ah how inadequate his hire!
All fails, if sickness be his fate;</br>He boasts no little store of wealth:</br>No balmy comforts on him wait;</br>No hand presents the cup of health.
His humble lot is hard at best,</br>And poverty his only meed:</br>While others are with plenty blest,</br>He feels the griping hand of need.
For food his craving children cry,</br>And oft assail the mother's ear;</br>Alas, in vain!  she heaves the sigh,</br>And sheds the silent secret tears.
Nought now her thrifty hand can spare,</br>Between the piteous stinted meal:</br>A scanty pittance is their share,</br>And pinching hunger oft they feel.
Nor to the peasant's cot alone;</br>Is pining poverty confin'd:</br>In cities wretched thousands moan,</br>To want and misery consign'd.
Here bloated luxury and pride,</br>The starving wretch regardless views:</br>Here want to decency's allied,</br>And mis'ry shews her various hues.
Here too vile war's destructive rage,</br>O'erturns the manufact'ring dome:</br>And those whom peaceful trade engage,</br>Are kill'd abroad, or starv'd at home.
Here oft the poor without employ,</br>The rich behold in mirth and ease;</br>Whilst they depriv'd of ev'ry joy,</br>Feel hunger, cold, and dire disease.
The artist who with patient hand,</br>Refines the ore, or works the loom;</br>Sinks midst the splendour of the land,</br>An early victim to the tomb.
And widow'd mothers, orphans dear,</br>And bleak misfortune's downcast train,</br>A dismal group forlorn appear,</br>Meek drudging sufferers of pain.
And all the hardy sons of toil,</br>Who once were happy, bold, and free;</br>In sorrow cultivate the soil,</br>Now forc'd to beg for charity.
Ah ye who neither toil nor spin,</br>Ye drones amidst the busy hive;</br>These are the men your battles win,</br>And by their labours 'tis ye thrive.
Think that on their laborious hands,</br>Depends the welfare of the state;</br>That by their strength it falls or stands;</br>Yet stern necessity's their fate.
In summer's heat and winter's cold,</br>Faintly their task of duty's spend:</br>Feeble the hands of young and old,</br>Life half-sustain'd — half cloth'd, half fed.
The savage in his native wild,</br>Naked, and roaming for his prey;</br>Who boasts no laws nor customs mild,</br>Is happier by far than they.
E'en from his home the negro torn,</br>By the vile bart'ring Christian knave;</br>And o'er the rude Atlantic borne,</br>To live and die an exil'd slave;
Is scarce more wretched and distress'd,</br>Than Britain's once most happy poor;</br>Who now by various ills oppress'd,</br>Their hapless lot in vain deplore.
Ye blund'ring politicians blush,</br>And know proud Statesmen to your shame;</br>'Tis your mad schemes the people crush,</br>And for their wrongs 'tis you they blame.
Dazzled with grandeur's gaudy blaze,</br>Ye seek but to support the crown;</br>Nor heed while basking in its rays,</br>That taxes weigh the nation down.
But oh!  ye good, ye wise, humane;</br>While venal Senates would enslave,</br>'Ere yet they bind the galling chain,</br>Step forward, and your country save!
And make, oh!  make the poor your care:</br>Let them by honest labour live;</br>Enjoy as erst their frugal fare,</br>And bless the gods for all they give.</br>
